title: The Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) has hundreds of oceanographic instruments that are collecting data every minute of every day from seven locations (arrays) throughout the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. For this activity we will be looking at data from the Coastal Endurance location in the Temperate Pacific Ocean (highlighted in red).
caption: Measuring the Ocean

title: Ocean Off of the Pacific Northwest
caption: The Coastal Endurance location is located in the ocean off of Oregon and Washington states. Data in this activity were collected from the Central Oregon Line (highlighted in red).

title: What it Looks Like Under the Water
caption: Below the ocean surface off of Oregon are multiple oceanographic instruments attached along cables running from the surface down to the seafloor in the Coastal Endurance location. This is a drawing to represent where the different instruments are located in the ocean. Data in this activity were collected from instruments on the Oregon Shelf Surface Mooring (E, highlighted in red).

title: What is on the Mooring?
caption: There are many moorings, multiple instruments connected to a wire cable and attached to the seafloor, in the OOI system. The instrument on the Oregon Shelf Surface Mooring that collected data in this activity is included in the Near Surface Instrument Frame (highlighted in red), which is attached to the cable 7m below the water surface. Multiple instruments, which are collecting data about many different oceanographic variables, are included in the Near Surface Instrument Frame. Data for this activity were collected using the Bulk Meteorology Instrument Package (METBK).

title: How does a METBK work?
caption: The Bulk Meteorology Instrument Package (METBK) measures a variety of parameters that characterize weather conditions above the sea surface, including the data required to compute air-sea fluxes of heat, freshwater, and momentum. The specific data products that are used in this activity are: Sea Surface Salinity (SALSURF), Air Temperature (TEMPAIR), Sea Surface Temperature (TEMPSRF), and Rain rate (RAINRTE).
